Title.evidence: Efficacy of Cell Salvage in Cardiac Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adult participants undergoing cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: evaluate the efficacy of Cell Salvage compared to allogeneic transfusions

Objective.evidence: This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Cell Salvage compared to allogeneic transfusions.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the effectiveness of Cell Salvage on hemoglobin levels, measured postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods varied across studies

Number_Randomised.evidence: Twenty-six studies with 2850 participants (1415 in the Cell Salvage group and 1435 in the control group) were included.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Cell Salvage showed moderate evidence of greater effectiveness for hemoglobin (mean difference = 0.48 g/dL, 95% CI 0.28 to 0.69) compared to allogeneic transfusions.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
